â€œAnyway,â€ I said once Persephone convinced the kid to go back to sleep, â€œhe canâ€™t hurt me. Heâ€™s not strong enough. So we balance. And when the whole thing happened with Zeus, he saved me. He trusted me, believed in me at a time when no one else could.â€

â€œThatâ€™s not actually him. I put him on this pedestal and made him into a symbol. He canâ€™t live up to that, you know?â€

Persephone nodded, knocking on the next door. â€œI get that.â€ Another empty room.

â€œUh-huh.â€ I couldnâ€™t imagine another being, least of all Persephone, â€œgettingâ€ something I barely understood about myself.

â€œNo, really, I do.â€ Persephone looked around the base of the bed. She raked her hair back, hand stopping at the top of her skull. â€œI used to get a crush on literally every guy who was ever nice to me. . . and it wasnâ€™t them, you know?â€ She flushed. â€œI always felt really out of place so Iâ€™d get really grateful when I got any attention at all. But I was too shy to act on my feelings, thank gods.â€

And I wasnâ€™t. Yup. Got that subtext loud and clear. â€œYou. . . think Iâ€™m insecure and desperate for affection?â€ I wasnâ€™t sure how to take that.

She pressed her lips together and glanced down at the carpet. â€œI think youâ€™re lonely. Iâ€™m not explaining this well.â€ She sighed. â€œIâ€™m saying I get it. I know what itâ€™s like to feel different and alone, and I know what itâ€™s like to seize onto that one kind gesture and to read so much into it that everything they say or do becomesâ€¦more. And youâ€™re right, putting him on a pedestal isnâ€™t fair to him, but itâ€™s also not fair to you because you end up putting all this stock into someone whoâ€¦maybe doesnâ€™t deserve it.â€

My throat went tight. â€œYeah.â€

~@~

Iâ€™ve talked about Unrequited Love on my blog before just two weeks ago. But the topic bears some expanding because two weeks ago, I mostly focused on the other person. The person who doesnâ€™t love back. How they feel. How frustrating it is that society keeps teaching us that not loving someone back if they just try hard enough is somehow wrong.

But it also sucks to be the person with all the feelings. To be the one wondering if you just said x or just did y, would they like you back. To over-analyze that personâ€™s every mood, to read things into their actions and not be able to tell if theyâ€™re real or if you just really want it to be real.

It sucks. And itâ€™s a sucky part of life. And acting on those feelings in a way thatâ€™s scary or vengeful or negative to them is unforgivable because the other sucky part of life is that they donâ€™t have to love you. But equally unforgivable is hurting yourself over it.Girls are particularly bad about this, statistically speaking, because from a societal stand point, weâ€™re expected to change. Oh, weâ€™re told not to, but the narrative weâ€™re fed doesnâ€™t match the message thatâ€™s preached. We are marketed to as a problem that can be fixed with the right make up or weight loss product. Movies and books and shows have running tropes where she joins his group, she acquires his interests, she compromises her beliefs, she changes her goals to fit his. When guys do that theyâ€™re seen as whipped, but when girls do it, itâ€™s par for the plot.

And to be fair, some changes going to happen no matter what. Donâ€™t change is stupid advice. You become the people youâ€™re around. Itâ€™s part of being a human. Your interests expand with your social circle, so do your friends, and your beliefs change when challenged. Thatâ€™s not a bad thing, I donâ€™t mean change as in go away. When you think from one perspective and are introduced to another, itâ€™s a sign of a working brain to assimilate the new information and reevaluate what you know to make it fit. But these changes should flow both ways. Itâ€™s problematic when one person is doing all the changing for another, especially if all this change is happening so the other person can be won.

But sometimes thereâ€™s something more serious at work than just disappointment that the other person doesnâ€™t return their affection. Like in the conversation with Persephone and Aphrodite above. The intense feelings they felt toward the boys in the examples had almost nothing to do with the actual boys and everything to do with turmoil happening in their own life. But those are just minor examples. Sometimes, itâ€™s a lot more serious.

People who hurt themselves, starve themselves, or sink into depression arenâ€™t doing it because so and so didnâ€™t love them back. So and so not loving them back was probably the end of a very long list of other issues impacting that personâ€™s life. So and so just likely happened to be the most concrete one that all those feelings could be hung on. And that is why those tropes are so scary. Because all the books and all the movies and all the shows take warning signs of really serious issues that demand really serious help, and trivializes them. That rhetoric has been so normalized that their parents, their friends, and possibly even themselves may not recognize a very real call for help. So pay attention to yourself, to your friends. Itâ€™s frighteningly easy to write someone off as desperate when thereâ€™s a lot more going on beneath the surface.

â€œYou know, if I had a gorgeous goddess following me, Iâ€™d slow down.â€

I turned, following the deep voice to its owner. Another demigod stood beside the silver set of double doors that led to the auditorium. He looked taller than Adonis, but about as muscular. If Adonis got into heavy steroids. Seriously, I couldnâ€™t decide if I felt impressed or frightened. Itâ€™s a thin line.

â€œTantalus.â€ He offered his hand, then shifted, grabbing me before I walked into the â€œPrivate Functionâ€ sign mounted on a gold pole. â€œWatch out.â€

Letting out an embarrassed laugh, I stumbled into Tantalus. I shouldnâ€™t be so hard on myself; Iâ€™ve only been walking for three years. It takes practice. â€œThanks.â€

â€œHere for the convention?â€ He kept his hands on my shoulders and didnâ€™t move away from me or out of the way of the door. Ignoring the people streaming around him, he looked me over. Clearly, he liked what he saw.

Finally! Some appreciation. I could do with a little more reverence and a little less attitude. Especially if it came from someone who looked like this.

Tantalus noticed me noticing him and puffed up with pride. My interest wavered. â€œUmâ€¦actuallyâ€¦â€ I didnâ€™t want to get into my whole investigation in this crowd. One on one, I could always charm him into not telling anyone what Iâ€™d shared and charm him into reporting to me if he saw anything suspicious. But in a room like this, there was no telling how far even a whisper could carry. Iâ€™d rather not waste the energy charming an entire convention into silence. I searched for another reason for being here, but drew a blank. â€œIâ€™ve always wanted to go on a cruise?â€

Stopping at the edge of the auditorium, I leaned against the back wall, soundproofing fuzzies tickling my bare arms. Adonis stood out like a golden beacon in the crowd, somehow managing to almost glow despite the dim light.

I scoped out the rest of the room, taking a moment to get my bearings. Booths, set up in semicircles so everyone seated could see the stage, spread to either side of the auditorium. The walls and tables were accented with silver swirls that glittered against the black. No one sat. The atmosphere in the room felt rushed and impatient. Sitting would indicate a time commitment no one seemed to want to fill.

Tantalus smirked and leaned against the wall beside me, hand planted right next to my head. â€œIâ€™d buy that, if I ran into you on deck.â€

What difference would that make? I cocked my head. â€œWhat is this anyway?â€

â€œOrientation.â€

Ah, for the convention. That made sense. â€œMaybe Iâ€™m just enjoying the view.â€

He beamed. Gods, men were so easy to flatter. Tantalus stepped in front of me, holding out his hands as if he were the gods gift to man. Which technically speakingâ€¦. â€œWell look no further, sweetheart.â€

A violent shudder wrenched through me at the term of endearment. I wrapped my arms around myself as if Iâ€™d shivered.

â€œCold?â€ His eyes flickered over me. â€œIf you want, we can ditch this and go someplace warmer.â€ His tone made the request behind his offer crystal clear.

I kept my eyes on Adonis, considering Tantalusâ€™ proposition. Well, not considering that angle of his proposition. I prefer men who worship me, not themselves.

Adonis stood in the center of the crowd, deep in conversation with a short, brunette woman. I did double take. She was one of the Plain Janes. The rest of the trio stood close by, chatting up another model. They were here for the modeling convention? Huh. Adonis nodded at something she said, not once looking away to search for me in the crowd.

No. I wasnâ€™t going to do this. Goddesses didnâ€™t follow guys around and stare at them across rooms hoping to catch them trying to steal a glance. A goddess did not pine. And as much as I wanted to convince myself that my only motivation to keep an eye on Adonis was my investigation, I knew that wasnâ€™t true.

But Tantalus? Tantalus wouldnâ€™t question me following him around. Heâ€™d actually welcome my attention. And I wouldnâ€™t be heartbroken if something happened to him. That made him good bait.

Tantalus was a demigod, the son of Zeus and a nymph. He was invited to a dinner on Olympus by Zeus, and while there stole ambrosia and nectar and the gods secrets. He also might have had a part in stealing Rheaâ€™s dog, but thatâ€™s debatable.

Following what I believe to be a pattern of Ambrosia driving demigods crazy (it is deadly to mortals, but demigods had it on occasion, often before doing incredibly stupid things with very little motive given) Tantalus made misguided effort to appease the gods by killing his son, Pelops, by boiling him alive, slicing him up, and serving him to the gods at dinner.

The gods caught on pretty quick to the human flavored feast before them and most of them did not partake. Demeter, distracted by her worry for her missing daughter, took a chunk out of the kids shoulder before realizing sheâ€™d consumed human flesh.

Tantalus was killed and sent to the depths of Tartarus for his crimes. His punishment was to stand ankle deep in water and look up at a cluster of grapes hung just out of reach as he starved and thirsted to death for all eternity. His location is a bit precarious as the giant boulder that another resident of Tartarus has to push up the hill everyday looms above him, precariously perched.

Meanwhile, the Fates gathered the body parts of poor Pelops, and Hephaestus made the kid a new shoulder out of ivory, marking him and his descendants, and he was brought back to life. Poseidon took the kid under his wing and taught him to race chariots until Zeus randomly decided Tantalusâ€™ entire family line needed to suffer. Tantalusâ€™ descendants became known as the cursed house of Atreus.

Pelops went on to win a chariot race for the hand of a woman named Hippodamia. But he won by cheating and sabotaging her fatherâ€™s chariot which crashed and killed him, but not before Hippodamiaâ€™s dad managed to curse Pelopsâ€™ house (descendants) with his dying breath.

Pelops and Hippodamia had two sons. Atreus and Thyestes. Pelops dies at some point and Hippodamia gets remarried. Her sons kill their new step brother and get exiled, Hippodamia hung herself in shame.

Somehow Atreus became king of the land they were banished to, Mycenae, and he was going to sacrifice his best golden lamb to Artemis, but decided to give it to his wife instead, who in turn gave it to his brother because she was sleeping with him. His brother convinced Atreus to say whoever possessed the golden lamb should rule, since Atreus thought the lamb was safely at his home he agreed, his brother produced the lamb and took over, saying his brother could take back over once the sun moved backward in the sky.

Atreus and Hermes convinced Zeus to make that happen, and Atreus became king again. Angered by his brotherâ€™s betrayal (sleeping with his wife and taking over his kingdom is pretty underhanded) Atreus exiled Thyestes, but not before he killed Thysestes kids by boiling them and slicing them up for dinner, and forced Thyestes to eat them. He kept the kids hands and feet as trophies and taunted Thyestes with the dismembered bits of his children.

Isnâ€™t Greek mythology fun ğŸ˜€

As his revenge, Thyestes slept with his niece, Atreusâ€™ daughter Pelopia. She had a son, Aegisthus, and abandoned him in the local sheep pen. A shepherd found the boy and presented him to Atreus who raised him as his own out of charity. Meanwhile, Atreus had two sons, Menelaus and Agamemnon. Thyestes came back on the scene, told Aegisthus his backstory, and sat back and watched while his son murdered Atreus.

Agamemnon married Clytemnestra, and Menelaus married Helen of Troy. When Paris took Helen to Troy, all hell broke loose, and Menelaus asked his brother for help. Agamemnon set sale right away, sacrificing his daughter Iphigenia to the gods so he could make better time. In some versions of the myth, Iphegenia was saved by Artemis (unbeknownst to anyone else) and sent to be a priestess.

Clytemnestra, furious that her firstborn daughter was killed, had an affair with Aegisthus (remember him? He killed Atreus, who was also his granddad and uncle) and the two plotted to kill Agamemnon when he returned home from the war. They succeeded, killing him in the bath tub with a net/funeral shroud, and then her other two children, Orestes and Electra, plotted to kill her to avenge their father.

Orestes was torn, and prayed to Apollo who advised him to kill his mother. He did, and Orestes was plagued by furies until Athena stepped in and a fair trial was held. Orestes was forgiven, and the gods stopped doing the whole punishing descendants for something their parents did thing. Thus ended the curse on the house of Atreus.

When our glasses arrived, Hades tested my drink before passing it to me. â€œIâ€™ve got her, Thanatos. Go on.â€

Thanatos studied me, looking so serious that I giggled. â€œHades, sheâ€™ll only embarrass herself. Let me get her out of theâ€”â€

â€œSure.â€

Hades gave Thanatos a look. â€œSatisfied?â€

Thanatos made a noncommittal noise and signaled a Lethian from the crowd.

Hades shook his head when Thanatos disappeared into the crowd. â€œHe worries too much.â€

â€œYouâ€™re not worried?â€

Something flickered in Hadesâ€™ eyes but it was gone before I could interpret it. â€œIt was probably an innocent mistake. But still . . . Iâ€™d rather not have you out of my sight.â€ He held out his hand. â€œStill want to dance?â€

Time passed in a blur of color and light. People laughed and danced around us, the spinning arcs of the skirts making me dizzy.

â€œI canâ€™t dance another step.â€ I giggled, clinging to Hades so I wouldnâ€™t trip and fall.

â€œLetâ€™s get some air.â€ Hades led me out of the ballroom. The party was scattered all across the Underworld, but we found privacy in the grove of trees. The trees stretched into the sky, their branches arching and spilling over, sheltering us from view of any of the other souls wandering the Underworld.

I imagined pomegranate seeds and a plastic baggy full of them appeared in my free hand. I put six seeds in my mouth. An owl hooted in the distance.

Ambrosia was the divine drink (and sometimes food and sometimes perfume for Aphrodite) of the gods. It is sometimes used interchangeably with Nectar, a divine drink. Other times Nectar is the drink and ambrosia is the food. Other times Nectar is the food and Ambrosia is the drink. For my purposes, Ambrosia is the â€œgolden Nectar of the gods.â€ Persephone drinks a glass in book one, and it gets her very, very drunk very, very fast. In my series itâ€™s the only drink that can actually get gods drunk, and the impact it has on humans is even more pronounced.

Depending on the myth, Ambrosia is either created by the earth in a sort of atmospheric offering to the gods and carried to Olympus by pretty gods, or Ambrosia was a nymph who was assaulted and turned into a grape vine to escape.

In mythology, the drink could turn mortals immortal, heal, and restore youth. It could also keep corpses fresh and life like for all time. Demigods drank it on occasion with no side effects, but the food/drink/perfume was jealously guarded from mortals. Tantalus was sent to a special place in hell because he tried to steal it. More on that in an upcoming Mythology Monday.

Thatâ€™s not to say that Ambrosia was never given to mortals, just not without a gods approval. Achilles was anointed with Ambrosia (except his heel) in some versions of the myth, and Psyche was annointed with Ambrosia at her wedding so she could marry Cupid.

Liquids like Ambrosia pop up in all kinds of lore. I use it more like fairy wine. There are references to ambrosia on Egyptian statues of Anubis. â€œI am deathâ€¦I eat ambrosia and drink blood.â€ Creepy much?

The passengers raised their arms in unison and slashed at the shield, the strobe lights turning the fluid motion jerky. The shield shuddered, but held.
